data.question: What are the benefits and harms of preoperative exercise training for people with non‐small cell lung cancer?
data.gold_answer: Preoperative exercise training may have some benefits for adults with lung cancer undergoing lung resection compared with usual care. In adults undergoing surgical resection for lung cancer, high‐ to moderate‐certainty evidence shows that preoperative exercise training (aerobic exercise and other types of exercise at different frequency, intensity, and duration) results in fewer postoperative pulmonary complications (on average, 159 vs 353 per 1000 people) and shorter hospital stay of around two days. Moderate‐ to very low‐certainty evidence suggests that exercise training also results in higher exercise capacity (postintervention), as well as greater lung function, as measured using forced expiratory volume in 1 second and forced vital capacity (around 5.9% and 5.4% predicted, respectively). Duration of intercostal catheter use after surgery was shorter with exercise by an average of two days; however, the results did not reach statistical significance. Reviewers noted no adverse effects in either treatment group that were attributable to the intervention. There was little to no difference between groups in postintervention dyspnea or postoperative mortality. It should be noted that the sample sizes of most trials were very small (19 to 151 participants), hence requiring caution in the interpretation of results.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CANCER (cancer): A disease of the cells.
RESECT (resect): remove or cut out surgically
PULMONARY (pulmonary): pertaining to the lungs
COMPLICATIONS (complications): Problems that develop after an operation, treatment or illness.
CATHETER (catheter): a tube placed near the spinal cord and used for anesthesia (indwelling epidural) during surgery
MORTALITY (mortality): death
data.llm_answer:
Preoperative exercise training for people with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) can have several benefits, including:
Benefits:
* Improved cardiovascular fitness and lung function
* Increased muscle strength and endurance
* Enhanced recovery after surgery
* Reduced risk of postoperative complications, such as pneumonia and respiratory failure
* Shorter hospital stay and faster return to daily activities
* Improved overall quality of life
However, there are also potential harms associated with preoperative exercise training for people with NSCLC, including:
Harms:
* Increased risk of fatigue and muscle soreness
* Potential for exercise-induced bronchospasm or other respiratory complications
* Risk of injury or exacerbation of existing medical conditions, such as osteoporosis or joint problems
* Increased anxiety or stress related to the exercise program
* Potential for negative impact on lung function in certain individuals, particularly those with severe lung disease
It is important to note that the benefits and harms of preoperative exercise training for people with NSCLC can vary depending on the individual's overall health status, the type and intensity of exercise, and the timing and duration of the exercise program. It is recommended that patients with NSCLC consult with their healthcare provider and an exercise physiologist or physical therapist to develop a personalized exercise program that takes into account their unique needs and health status.

data.question: For adults with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and cutaneous disease, what are the effects of intravenous (IV)/subcutaneous (SC) monoclonal antibodies?
data.gold_answer: Compared with placebo for adults with SLE and cutaneous disease, belimumab probably improves skin‐specific measures of disease activity, with little to no impact on severe adverse events, and tabalumab may result in little to no difference in adverse events. Available information for other monoclonal antibodies is limited. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that among adults with SLE and cutaneous disease, skin‐specific measures of SLE disease activity at 12 months would probably be improved with IV belimumab 1 and 10 mg/kg than with placebo, but the result was imprecise for belimumab 1 mg/kg for the specific score "no more than 1 new BILAG [British Isles Lupus Assessment Group] B flare.” There was little to no difference between groups in severe adverse events, and results for minor events were imprecise. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that, compared with placebo, SC tabalumab may lead to little to no difference in minor and severe adverse events. Compared with placebo, rituximab 1000 mg IV two doses given 14 days apart resulted in inconclusive effects for skin‐specific measures of SLE disease activity (BILAG) at 12 months and for minor and severe adverse events. Compared with placebo, lulizumab SC 1.25 to 12.5 mg weekly or every other week for 6 months led to inconclusive results for skin‐specific measures of SLE disease activity and imprecise results for severe adverse events. Comparisons of epratuzumab, sifalimumab, sirukumab, ustekinumab, and anifrolumab versus placebo were evaluated in too few participants to yield reliable results.
data.gold_answer_terms:
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
CUTANEOUS (cutaneous): relating to the skin
DISEASE (disease): An abnormal condition in the body causing harm.
ANTIBODY (antibody): protein made in the body in response to foreign substance
IV (iv): through the vein
LUPUS (lupus): A condition caused by your immune system mistakenly attacking healthy cells in your body. Symptoms may include problems with your skin, joints and kidneys; extreme tiredness and muscle pain.
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at

data.question: What are the effects of quarantining travelers crossing international borders (with or without screening) on the spread of COVID‐19?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers identified 18 modeling and observational studies that assessed the impact on the spread of COVID‐19 of quarantine of travelers alone or in combination with entry and/or exit screening during or after quarantine. These studies provided low‐ to very low‐certainty evidence suggesting that quarantine alone may reduce the risk/probability of releasing an infected individual into the community (by 0% to 85%), the number of days travelers remain at risk of transmitting the infection into the community upon release (by 0.1 to 2.1 days), the proportion of imported cases (by 55% after a 7‐day quarantine, and by 91% after a 14‐day quarantine), the number/proportion of cases in the community (by 450 to 64,028 cases), and the number/proportion of cases seeded by imported cases (by 26% to 100%), and may increase case detection (to 51% after a 7‐day quarantine, and to 78% after a 14‐day quarantine) and delay the peak in active cases and deaths (by 3.5 and 5.5 days, when effectiveness was assumed to be 80% and 90%, respectively). When screening was added to quarantine, evidence suggests the risk/probability of releasing an infected individual into the community may be reduced by 2% to 48%, the days a traveler is at risk of transmitting the infection into the community upon release may be reduced by 0.01 to 2.0 days, case detection may be increased by 41% to 99%, and delay to outbreak may be delayed by 3.5 to 34.1 years depending on the combination of measures.
data.gold_answer_terms:
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at
SCREENING (screening): A test or set of tests to check for a condition in a person who shows no symptoms, but who may be at risk (perhaps because of their age or sexual behaviour, for example).
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
data.llm_answer:
Quarantining travelers crossing international borders can help slow the spread of COVID-19, but it is not a foolproof measure. The effectiveness of quarantine in preventing the spread of COVID-19 depends on several factors, including the duration of quarantine, the level of compliance, and the effectiveness of screening measures.
Studies have shown that quarantine can significantly reduce the spread of COVID-19, particularly when combined with other measures such as testing, contact tracing, and isolation of infected individuals. However, quarantine alone may not be sufficient to completely stop the spread of the virus, especially in cases where infected individuals are not symptomatic or where there are lapses in compliance.
Moreover, quarantine can have significant social and economic impacts, including disruptions to supply chains, loss of productivity, and increased isolation and stigma for quarantined individuals.
Therefore, while quarantining travelers crossing international borders can be a useful tool in slowing the spread of COVID-19, it should be used in conjunction with other measures and tailored to the specific circumstances of each situation. It is also important to consider the ethical and legal implications of quarantine and to ensure that the rights and well-being of quarantined individuals are protected.

data.llm_answer:
Quarantining travelers crossing international borders can have several effects on the spread of COVID-19, both positive and negative.
Positive effects:
1. Reduced transmission risk: Quarantining travelers can help reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19 by separating infected individuals from others who may be susceptible to the virus. This can help slow down the spread of the virus, particularly in areas with high infection rates.
2. Time for testing and contact tracing: Quarantine periods can provide time for health authorities to test travelers for COVID-19 and conduct contact tracing to identify individuals who may have been in close contact with infected travelers.
3. Reduced spread through international travel: Quarantining travelers can help reduce the spread of COVID-19 through international travel, as infected individuals are less likely to travel while they are in quarantine.
Negative effects:
1. Economic impact: Quarantining travelers can have significant economic impacts, particularly on industries that rely heavily on international travel, such as tourism and trade.
2. Social distancing challenges: Quarantine measures can create challenges for social distancing, as people may be forced to gather in close proximities while waiting for their quarantine period to end.
3. Stigma and discrimination: Quarantine measures can also lead to stigma and discrimination against individuals who have been quarantined, which can have negative effects on their mental health and well-being.
4. Difficulty in enforcement: Quarantine measures can be difficult to enforce, particularly in areas with limited resources or where there is a lack of political will to enforce them.
It's important to note that the effectiveness of quarantining travelers in preventing the spread of COVID-19 is highly dependent on several factors, including the length of the quarantine period, the level of testing and contact tracing, and the level of cooperation from the public. Additionally, quarantine measures should be implemented in conjunction with other public health measures, such as vaccination, social distancing, and personal protective equipment (PPE) use, to maximize their effectiveness.

data.question: What are the effects of fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) for people with ulcerative colitis?
data.gold_answer: Low‐certainty evidence suggests that more people with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis undergoing FMT achieved clinical remission (Simple Clinical Colitis Activity Index [SCCAI] ≤ 2 or Mayo score < 2 or 3) at 6 to 12 weeks compared with those given a control intervention (autologous fecal administration or placebo) (153 vs 86 per 1000 people; all results on average). Based on evidence of the same grade, more people receiving FMT achieved endoscopic remission at 8 to 12 weeks (Mayo score ≤ 2 or SCCAI < 3) (109 vs 75 per 1000 people). There was little to no difference between groups in adverse events (such as abdominal pain, nausea, flatulence, bloating, headaches, and dizziness). Results for quality of life and serious adverse events were very uncertain, and any conclusions regarding clinical or endoscopic response were precluded by an insufficient number of participants in the analyses.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
REMISSION (remission): disappearance of evidence of cancer or other disease
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
ABDOMINAL (abdominal): Of the abdomen.
data.llm_answer: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) has been shown to be effective in treating people with ulcerative colitis, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Studies have consistently demonstrated that FMT can induce remission in patients with active ulcerative colitis, with response rates ranging from 50% to 90%. Additionally, FMT has been shown to improve quality of life, reduce inflammation, and decrease the need for medications such as steroids and immunosuppressants. However, it is important to note that FMT is not a cure for ulcerative colitis, and some patients may require ongoing maintenance therapy to maintain remission. As with any medical treatment, there are potential risks and side effects associated with FMT, including infection and colonoscopy-related complications. It is important to discuss the benefits and risks of FMT with a healthcare provider to determine if it is an appropriate treatment option for an individual patient.

Based on evidence of the same grade, more people receiving FMT achieved endoscopic remission at 8 to 12 weeks (Mayo score ≤ 2 or SCCAI < 3) (109 vs 75 per 1000 people). There was little to no difference between groups in adverse events (such as abdominal pain, nausea, flatulence, bloating, headaches, and dizziness). Results for quality of life and serious adverse events were very uncertain, and any conclusions regarding clinical or endoscopic response were precluded by an insufficient number of participants in the analyses.
data.gold_answer_terms:
CLINICAL (clinical): pertaining to medical care
REMISSION (remission): disappearance of evidence of cancer or other disease
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
ABDOMINAL (abdominal): Of the abdomen.
data.llm_answer: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) has been shown to be effective in treating ulcerative colitis, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Studies have consistently demonstrated that FMT can induce remission in patients with active ulcerative colitis, and can also improve quality of life and reduce the need for medication. Additionally, FMT has been found to be safe and well-tolerated, with minimal side effects. However, it is important to note that FMT is not a cure for ulcerative colitis, and more research is needed to understand its long-term effects and how it compares to other treatment options. It is also important to note that FMT should only be performed by a trained healthcare professional, and should not be attempted at home.

data.question: For children and adults with eczema, how does twice or more daily topical corticosteroids (TCS) compare with once‐daily TCS?
data.gold_answer: For children and adults with eczema, moderate‐certainty evidence shows little to no difference between applying TCS twice or more and applying it once daily in clinician‐reported signs of eczema at one to four weeks. Low‐certainty evidence suggests there is no clear impact of one schedule over the other either on patient‐reported signs of eczema or local adverse events at one to six weeks. Evidence for systemic adverse events was of very low certainty. Of note, 90% of the studies were published between 1981 and 1999.
data.gold_answer_terms: LOCALIZED (localized): restricted to one area, limited to one area
data.llm_answer: Twice or more daily topical corticosteroids (TCS) are more effective than once-daily TCS in controlling eczema symptoms in children and adults, according to a Cochrane review of 17 randomized controlled trials. The increased frequency of application was associated with better reduction in inflammation and itching, but also with a higher risk of side effects such as skin thinning and infections. It is important to note that the optimal frequency and potency of TCS application should be individualized and determined by a healthcare professional.

data.question: How do mepolizumab and benralizumab compare with placebo for reducing exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in adults?
data.gold_answer: For adults with COPD and an exacerbation and eosinophilic phenotype, 100 mg mepolizumab (monthly) reduces the incidence of moderate to severe exacerbations compared with placebo (around 1.3 vs 1.6 per year) and reduces the time to first exacerbation over 52 weeks. Among adults with COPD and a history of exacerbations but no eosinophilic elevation, benralizumab does not reduce the rate of moderate to severe exacerbation over 56 weeks compared with placebo. However, for COPD patients receiving 10 or 100 mg benralizumab (4 to 8 weekly) who have elevated blood eosinophils (≥ 220/μL), the rate of severe exacerbations requiring hospitalization is reduced compared with placebo (around 0.22 vs 0.32 per year with 10 mg, and 0.18 vs 0.29 with 100 mg). Neither medication led to a clinically important improvement in health‐related quality of life or reduction in mortality, but both appeared to cause no increase in adverse events.

data.question: What are the effects of different interventions for the prevention of persistent post‐COVID‐19 olfactory dysfunction?
data.gold_answer: Low‐certainty evidence suggests there is little to no difference in normal olfactory function at > 4 weeks to 3 months between intranasal steroid drops and placebo. The available evidence assessing other interventions (intranasal corticosteroid spray, intranasal hypertonic saline spray, or oral zinc sulphate) is of very low certainty and therefore prevents any definitive conclusions regarding this clinical question.

There is currently limited research on the effects of interventions for the prevention of persistent post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction. However, some studies suggest that the following interventions may be beneficial:
1. Olfactory training: This involves exercises that aim to stimulate the olfactory system and promote neuroplasticity. Studies have shown that olfactory training can improve olfactory function in patients with olfactory dysfunction.
2. Nasal saline irrigation: This involves rinsing the nasal passages with a saline solution to remove inflammatory mediators and promote nasal cleansing. Some studies suggest that nasal saline irrigation may improve olfactory function in patients with post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction.
3. Antioxidant supplements: Oxidative stress may contribute to olfactory dysfunction. Antioxidant supplements, such as vitamin C and E, may help to reduce oxidative stress and improve olfactory function.
4. Steroids: Corticosteroids may help to reduce inflammation in the nasal passages and improve olfactory function. However, the long-term effects of steroid use are not well established, and their use should be carefully monitored.
5. Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy: PRP therapy involves injecting platelet-rich plasma into the nasal passages to stimulate healing and regeneration of the olfactory epithelium. Some studies suggest that PRP therapy may improve olfactory function in patients with post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction.
It is important to note that these interventions are not universally effective and may have varying degrees of success in different individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand the effects of these interventions and to identify the most effective treatments for persistent post-COVID-19 olfactory dysfunction.

data.question: For people with acute kidney injury, how does early initiation of kidney replacement therapy (KRT) compare with standard initiation?
data.gold_answer: For adults admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute kidney injury and compared with standard initiation of KRT, low‐certainty evidence suggests that early initiation of KRT (within 6 to 12 hours of documentation of Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes [KDIGO] stage 2 to 3) does not seem to affect mortality or the composite outcome of death or non‐recovery of kidney function. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows a likely shorter duration of ICU stay with early initiation (by one day; all results on average). High‐certainty evidence shows that risk of hypophosphatemia, hypotension, and cardiac‐rhythm disorder is higher with early initiation than with standard initiation (with a difference of 34, 31, and 5 per 1000 people, respectively), despite that results for any adverse events were very uncertain.
data.gold_answer_terms:
ACUTE (acute): new, recent, sudden, urgent
KIDNEY (kidney): The body’s two kidneys keep fluids balanced by filtering the blood. Waste products are then excreted as urine.
DISEASE (disease): An abnormal condition in the body causing harm.
STAGING (staging): an evaluation of the extent of the disease
MORTALITY (mortality): death
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
HYPOTENSION (hypotension): low blood pressure
data.llm_answer: Early initiation of kidney replacement therapy (KRT) in people with acute kidney injury (AKI) has been shown to improve survival and reduce the risk of complications compared to standard initiation. Early initiation is typically defined as starting KRT within 24-48 hours of AKI diagnosis, while standard initiation is typically defined as starting KRT after 48-72 hours. Studies have shown that early initiation of KRT is associated with lower mortality rates, shorter hospital stays, and reduced need for mechanical ventilation and dialysis. However, early initiation may also be associated with higher rates of renal recovery and discontinuation of KRT. The optimal timing of KRT initiation in AKI remains a topic of debate and should be individualized based on patient factors and clinical context.

data.question: What are the effects of exercise‐based cardiac rehabilitation for people with coronary heart disease?
data.gold_answer: Exercise‐based cardiac rehabilitation programs seem to reduce fatal and/or nonfatal myocardial infarction (MI), cardiovascular mortality, and hospital admissions and improve quality of life over standard medical care for lower‐risk patients with coronary heart disease (CHD). High‐certainty evidence shows that fewer people had fatal and/or nonfatal MI with exercise than with usual care at 6 to 12 months (29 vs 40 per 1000 people; all results on average), and moderate‐certainty evidence shows that exercise‐based rehabilitation may slightly reduce all‐cause mortality at 6 to 12 months (45 vs 52 per 1000 people), although the difference between groups did not reach statistical significance. Cardiovascular mortality appears to be reduced by exercise at > 12 months to 36 months (106 vs 138 per 1000 people; based on 3614 participants) and at > 3 years (90 vs 156 per 1000 people; based on 1392 participants). In the short term (follow‐up of 6 to 12 months), moderate‐certainty evidence shows a lower rate of hospital admissions (103 vs 179 per 1000 people), but this does not seem to persist over the longer term. Reviewers reported improvement in health‐related quality of life at 6 to 12 months with cardiac rehabilitation but similar rates of patients needing revascularization in both groups. It is worth noting, however, that most studies consisted predominantly of lower‐risk young men, which limits generalization of these findings to other groups of patients with CHD, especially women and higher‐risk men, including those with angina pectoris or with major comorbidities.

data.question: What are the effects of exercise‐based cardiac rehabilitation for people with coronary heart disease?
data.gold_answer: Exercise‐based cardiac rehabilitation programs seem to reduce fatal and/or nonfatal myocardial infarction (MI), cardiovascular mortality, and hospital admissions and improve quality of life over standard medical care for lower‐risk patients with coronary heart disease (CHD). High‐certainty evidence shows that fewer people had fatal and/or nonfatal MI with exercise than with usual care at 6 to 12 months (29 vs 40 per 1000 people; all results on average), and moderate‐certainty evidence shows that exercise‐based rehabilitation may slightly reduce all‐cause mortality at 6 to 12 months (45 vs 52 per 1000 people), although the difference between groups did not reach statistical significance. Cardiovascular mortality appears to be reduced by exercise at > 12 months to 36 months (106 vs 138 per 1000 people; based on 3614 participants) and at > 3 years (90 vs 156 per 1000 people; based on 1392 participants). In the short term (follow‐up of 6 to 12 months), moderate‐certainty evidence shows a lower rate of hospital admissions (103 vs 179 per 1000 people), but this does not seem to persist over the longer term. Reviewers reported improvement in health‐related quality of life at 6 to 12 months with cardiac rehabilitation but similar rates of patients needing revascularization in both groups. It is worth noting, however, that most studies consisted predominantly of lower‐risk young men, which limits generalization of these findings to other groups of patients with CHD, especially women and higher‐risk men, including those with angina pectoris or with major comorbidities.

data.question: What are the effects of as‐required fixed‐dose combination beta agonist plus steroid inhaler for adults with mild asthma?
data.gold_answer: As‐required use of a fixed‐dose fast‐acting beta agonist (FABA) plus inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) combination inhaler (FABA/ICS) seems to be more effective than other as‐required regimens for adults with mild asthma. High‐certainty evidence shows that as‐required FABA/ICS in adults with mild asthma was more effective than as‐required FABA alone for decreasing asthma exacerbations requiring systemic steroids (53 vs 110 per 1000 people; all results on average). Low‐certainty evidence suggests that as‐required FABA/ICS reduced exacerbations requiring hospital admission or emergency department/urgent‐care visits, compared with as‐required FABA alone (4 vs 12 per 1000 people). FABA/ICS also improved asthma control as measured by ACQ‐5 score and reduced total systemic corticosteroid dose, with fewer people reporting adverse events (379 vs 427 per 1000 people). Daily inhaled steroid dose was higher with as‐required FABA/ICS than with as‐required FABA. In adults with mild asthma, low‐certainty evidence suggests that as‐required FABA/ICS may have been more effective than regular inhaled steroids plus as‐required FABA for reducing asthma exacerbations requiring systemic steroids (67 vs 83 per 1000 people); however, the differences between groups did not reach statistical significance. Low‐certainty evidence also suggests that as‐required FABA/ICS was more effective than regular inhaled steroids plus as‐required FABA for reducing exacerbations requiring hospital admission or emergency department/urgent care visits (11 vs 17 per 1000 people). FABA/ICS lowered daily inhaled steroid dose and total systemic corticosteroid dose; however, FABA/ICS was less effective for improving ACQ‐5 scores than regular ICS. There was no difference in adverse events between the two treatment groups.

data.question: What effect do adjunctive corticosteroids have on mortality and disability in people with tuberculous meningitis?
data.gold_answer: High‐quality evidence shows that children and adults with a clinical diagnosis of tuberculosis (TB) meningitis receiving an anti‐TB regimen are less likely to die within 24 months when an adjunctive corticosteroid is administered (312 versus 413 per 1000 people died with an adjunctive corticosteroid compared with no corticosteroid, respectively). Moderate‐quality evidence showed that this benefit was not sustained in the longer‐term (5 years). Low‐quality evidence suggests there was no benefit of an adjunctive corticosteroid in terms of reducing rates of disabling neurological deficit, ether within 24 months or at 5 years. There was no apparent impact of adjunctive corticosteroids on the incidences of hepatitis, hyperglycemia/glycosuria, gastrointestinal bleeding, or invasive bacterial infection but event rates were very low meaning conclusions cannot be drawn.

data.question: Can probiotics administered to pregnant women help prevent morbidity and mortality in preterm infants?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers found no conclusive RCT evidence suggesting that administration of probiotics to pregnant women was superior or inferior to placebo in reducing morbidity or mortality in preterm infants. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that in pregnant women who received probiotics, the risk of preterm birth (< 37 weeks) and miscarriage/stillbirth was no more or less likely compared with those who did not receive probiotics. Only one RCT (159 infants) reported no incidences of early neonatal sepsis (≤ 3 days) in either trial arm. For most outcomes, event rates were very low or there were no events in both arms. There is a lack of data on neonatal short‐term (early or late sepsis, necrotizing enterocolitis, neonatal death, hospital stay) and long‐term (major neurodevelopmental disability) potential benefits or harms following probiotic administration. None of the trials included women with a previous history of preterm birth, multiple pregnancy, or uterine anomaly. Reviewers did not assess serious adverse maternal or neonatal adverse events following use of probiotics.
data.gold_answer_terms:
RCT (rct): A study which tests the effectiveness and safety of treatments or procedures as fairly and objectively as possible. By randomly assigning patients to different treatments for the same problem, the results can be assessed equally with the aim of discovering the best possible procedure for the condition.
PLACEBO (placebo): an inactive substance; a pill/liquid that contains no medicine
MORBIDITY (morbidity): undesired result or complication
MORTALITY (mortality): death
RISK (risk): The chance that an activity or hazard will give rise to harm. Risk is generally given in terms of numerical odds (1 in 10) or percentages (10%).
SEPSIS (sepsis): The immune system's overreaction to an infection or injury which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death.
POTENTIAL (potential): possible
POTENTIATE (potentiate): increase or multiply the effect of a drug or toxin (poison) by giving another drug or toxin at the same time (sometimes an unintentional result)
POTENTIATOR (potentiator): an agent that helps another agent work better
ASSESS (assess): to learn about, measure, evaluate, look at
